doc.repnme: Honduras - Monitoring country progress in drinking water and sanitation (MAPAS)
doc.abstracts: This report presents the results of a sector analysis and dialogue carried out during the implementation of the Monitoring Country Progress in Drinking Water and Sanitation (MAPAS) regional initiative in Honduras. Statistics mask significant inequalities and disparities between urban and rural areas; significant majorities of people lacking access to water supply and sanitation (WSS) services live in rural areas. The MAPAS analysis generated a scorecard which evaluates the service delivery pathway in four subsectors of water supply and sanitation (WSS): rural water, urban water, rural sanitation and hygiene, and urban sanitation and hygiene. The report lists priority actions suggested for each subsector. The results indicate that it is essential to complete the institutional reform process started in 2003 with the Framework Law for the Drinking Water and Sanitation Sector. Service providers must be strengthened by decentralizing urban services to the municipalities and empowering local post-construction support mechanisms. All sector institutions and decision makers in Honduras emphasized the need for an effective governing body and an autonomous regulatory authority to: apply sector policies and promote coordination between sector institutions and municipalities; shift from annual institutional planning to a sector-wide programmatic planning approach; use equity criteria to direct investment toward underserved populations; grant WSS utilities autonomy to recover costs and improve sustainability; and incorporate climate change adaptation and disaster risk management measures. The financial assessment also revealed the need to ensure sufficient funds to rehabilitate and replace systems that are approaching the end of their lifespan. Finally, ensuring systematic compilation of information from all sector agencies is critical for investment planning and improvement of WSS services.
